text: that's so cool I've never seen hair like
that before if you go 2,000 kilometres
north of Brisbane and 1,500 kilometres
east of Papua New Guinea you'll come
across a beautiful chain of a Thousand
Island called I'm here in my hundred and
fifty fourth country and the start of my
three-week trip around the Pacific
Islands everybody knows that this part
of the world has beautiful beaches and
swaying coconut trees so I'm not going
to bore you with that content over the
coming weeks what you can expect to see
is the unique culture and local life
that exists on each Island which I'm
very eager to explore we're here at the
Central Market or the main market in
Honiara
what I find most unique about the
Solomon Islands so far is that some of
the locals have this amazing blonde hair
at first I thought it was fake or dyed
but then I realised that it's a hundred
percent natural it's natural
all of you have natural hair when I
think of blonde hair
I think of Sweden or Russia or the US or
Australia basically all countries with
native white people but in the Solomon
Islands people here are of Melanesian
descent and mostly have darker skin a
quick Google search led me to a study by
Stanford Medical School it discovered
that blondes make up five to ten percent
of the sullivan island population and
the gene was not passed down by european
explorers or traders it's a completely
homegrown genetic strand that only
exists here i think the baby has blonde
hair - the next generation of blonds
right here why well they don't exactly
know maybe it's the sun exposure or
their heavy diet of fish pulled over on
the side of the road here to get some
grilled fish and cassava but whatever
the reason may be
it's so cool to witness this bright
blonde hair on people with dark skin
more stories coming from the solomon
islands tomorrow i'm drew pinsky and if
